discussion.content:
I agree with C, There is one Primary and 2 Secondary
Total supported is 1 Primary and 7 Secondary

comments.content: D is correct, you "cannot" select the secondary role. The secondary role is auto assigned in multi-site environment: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-Data-Center-for-vSphere/6.2/nsx_62_cross_vc_install.pdf (page 25)

discussion.content: I Agree. Answer is C. Please correct and update please

questions.question_text: An administrator is deploying NSX in a Cross-vCenter configuration across three data centers located 100 miles apart Datacenter-1 and Datacenter-3 already have NSX deployed locally and Datacenter-2 does not have NSX deployed yet. What is the correct order of steps to configure all three data centers for this solution?

choices.C: 1 Deploy an NSX manager in Datacenter 2 2 Update the NSX manager role in Datacenter-1 to Primary 3 Update the roles in Dafacenter-2 and Datacentar-3 to Secondary 4 Deploy a universal transport zone
choices.B: 1 Deploy an NSX manager at Dataeenter-2 2 Change the roles of the NSX managers in Datacentar-1 and Datacenter-3 to Transit Mode 3 Deploy a universal transport zone 4 Configure the Primary and Secondary roles on all three NSX managers
choices.D: 1 Deploy the NSX manager at Datacenter-2 2 Update the NSX manager role in Datacenter-1 to Primary 3 Deploy a universal transport zone 4 Deploy a universal distributed logical router
choices.A: 1 Remove the NSX manager from Datacenter-1 and Datacenter-3 2 Reinstall all three NSX managers at the same time 3 Deploy a universal transport zone 4 Deploy a universal distributed logical router

choices.C: NSX Manager must be registered with Active Directory
choices.B: Inventory Service must be registered with a domain account
choices.D: NSX Controller must be registered with Active Directory
choices.A: Guest Introspection virtual machines must be joined to the domain

questions.question_text: A security administrator needs to create a Security Group based on an Active Directory group. However, AD Groups are not available as an option. What must the administrator configure before AD Groups are available?
What is one of the benefits of a spine-leaf network topology?

choices.A: A loop prevention protocol is not required
choices.C: Allows for VXl ANs to be defined in h traditional network topology
choices.B: Automatic propagation of security policies to all nodes
choices.D: Network virtualization relies on spine leaf topologies to create logical switches

discussion.content: A should be the answer, Spine leaf architecture doesnt run loop prevention protocol.
Sorry I meant to say, Spine leaf does require loop free prevention protocols, such as MLAG/VPC based on LACP for L2SL and ECMP based on BGP/OSPF for L3SL...So D is correct answer...
Spine/leaf architecture does run loop free protocols, such as MLAG/VPC for L2SP (L2 Spine Leaf) or ECMP for L3SP....So A is correct answer...

NSX doesn't care what is underlying topology. It just need connectivity for its functioning. Spine-leaf is based on Layer 3 , so usual layer 2 loop prevention protocols doesn't apply and are not needed.
Layer 3 prevents loops using split horizon. Also, it is dependent what routing protocol you're using. Leaf and spine topology either utilizes IS-IS or BGP routing protocols which have their own loop prevention mechanism.
